content.text: Using the values of \(x\) and \(y\) in the first row of the table, calculate the mass \(M\) of the rule using the equation
M =
Repeat step (a)(i) using the values of \(x\) and \(y\) in the second row of the table
M =
Calculate the average value of \(M\)
average value of \(M =\)   .........
**Method 2.**
The student measures the mass \(M\) of the rule, using a spring balance as shown Fig. 1.2
Write down the reading shown in Fig. 1.2
The student expects that the values of the mass \(M\) obtained by the two methods exactly the same
Suggest two practical reasons why, in spite of following the instructions with care, the values may differ. Assume that the balance used in Method 2 is accurate
Explain briefly how you would judge the position of the centre of the mass \(\mathbf{X}\) when it is on the rule in Method 1. You may draw a diagram
The IGCSE class is determining the mass of a metre rule using two methods
**Method 1.**
Fig. 1.1 shows the apparatus used

A student places a \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass \(\mathbf{X}\) on the rule so that its centre is at a distance \(d = 5.0\mathrm{cm}\) from the zero end of the rule, as shown in Fig. 1.1. He adjusts the position of the rule so that it is as near as possible to being balanced
He measures the distance \(x\) from the centre of the mass \(\mathbf{X}\) to the pivot and the distance \(y\) from the pivot to the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark on the rule
He repeats the procedure using \(d = 10.0 \text{cm}\)
The readings are shown in Table 1.1
A student places a thermometer in a beaker of cold water
Using Fig. 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{C}}\) of the cold water supplied to the student
The student pours \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into a beaker. She measures the temperature of the water at 30 s intervals. The readings are shown in Table 2.1
Complete the column headings in the table
The student empties the beaker and pours another \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water into the beaker. She measures the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{L}}\) of the water in the beaker
She then empties the cold water from the measuring cylinder shown in Fig. 2.2 into the beaker of hot water. She measures the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the water in the beaker
Estimate the volume \(V\) of cold water that, added to the hot water, would give the same temperature drop as allowing the hot water to cool for 150s
Use the evidence from the table and the readings in parts **(b)** and **(c)**. Explain briefly how you arrived at your answer
This laboratory investigation could be used as a small-scale model for a process in a factory. The laboratory investigation would be repeated many times
Suggest two conditions that should be kept constant in order to provide reliable results
The IGCSE class is investigating the cooling of water
Using Fig. 3.2, record the student's readings
Calculate the resistance \(R_{1}\) of lamp 1 using the equation \(R_{1} = \frac{V_{1}}{I}\)
Using Fig. 3.3, record the student's reading of \(V_{2}\)
Using Fig. 3.4, record the student's reading of \(V_{3}\)
The student uses the voltmeter to measure the potential difference \(V_{2}\) across and the potential difference \(V_{3}\) across lamp 3
Calculate the total potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{T}}\) across the three lamps using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{T}} = V_{1} + V_{2} + V_{3}\)
The student rearranges the circuit so that the lamps are in parallel with each other the ammeter is connected to measure the total current \(I_{\mathrm{T}}\) in the circuit
He connects the voltmeter to measure the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\) across the lamps
In the space below, draw a circuit diagram of this new circuit using standard symbols
The student measures the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\) and the current \(I_{\mathrm{T}}\), and calculates the total resistance \(R_{\mathrm{p}}\) of the lamps arranged in parallel
The student suggests that \(R_{\mathrm{p}}\) should be equal to \(\frac{R_{1}}{3}\)
State whether the results support this suggestion and justify your answer by reference to the results
statement
justification
Another student suggests that \(R_{\mathrm{p}}\) should not be equal to \(\frac{R_{1}}{3}\) because the lamp fila
are hotter when the lamps are connected in parallel than when the lamps are connected in series
State one piece of evidence, that you would see during the investigation, that shows that the lamp filaments are hotter in the parallel circuit
The IGCSE class is investigating resistor combinations in circuits
The first circuit used is shown in Fig. 3.1
A student measures the potential difference \(V_{1}\) across lamp 1 and the current \(I\) in the circuit
The period \(T\) of the pendulum is the time taken for one complete oscillation
For each set of readings in the table, calculate the period \(T\) and enter the results in the table
Suggest a reason for measuring the time for twenty oscillations rather than just
In this experiment, the length \(x\) of the string is measured with a metre rule
Suggest one precaution that you would take when measuring the length in order to obtain an accurate reading
The student decides that a more useful result is possible if the length is measured to the centre of mass of the pendulum bob
The pendulum bob is a small metal ball. The student has a \(30\mathrm{cm}\) ruler and two rectangular blocks of wood that are about \(10\mathrm{cm}\) long
Suggest how the student can use this equipment to measure accurately the diameter of the pendulum bob. You may draw a diagram
A student carries out an experiment using a simple pendulum
Fig. 4.1 shows the apparatus
The student records the time \(t\) taken for 20 complete oscillations of the pendulum for a range of different lengths \(x\) of the string. The readings are shown in Table 4.1
Plot a graph of \(u / \text{cm}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(\frac{1}{h} /\frac{1}{\text{cm}}\) (\(x\)-axis). You do not need to begin the at the origin (0,0)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
Calculate the focal length \(f\) of the lens, using the equation \(f = \frac{G}{1.5} \text{ cm}\). Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
State two precautions that you would take in this experiment in order to obtain results
The IGCSE class is determining the focal length of a lens
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 5.1

A student places the lens a distance \(u = 25.0 \text{cm}\) from an illuminated object of height \(1.5 \text{cm}\). She moves the screen until a sharply focused image of the object is seen on the screen
She measures the height \(h\) of the image on the screen. She calculates \(\frac{1}{h}\)
She repeats the procedure using a range of \(u\) values. Her results are shown in Table 5.1
